page.title: 07Farming 2: Weather & Soil
page.content: The climate of this area is difficult for farming and because the farms are on top of the Downs the mist, which contains salt from the sea, blows over the land and scorches the grass. The salt (sodium chloride) reacts with the crops and causes combustion, although if the crops are killed off during the winter, farmers can always plant spring barley. The solution is really to grow crops and rear dairy cattle. If the weather is wet then you can be sure of a good dairy product even if the crops fail. The soil in this area is not ideal for farming. Certain parts of the area have only a few inches of topsoil above the chalk; other areas have eight feet of clay on top of the chalk. Throughout the ground is full of flint.
